trans-unit.source: Connect to an on-premises SQL Server from an Azure mobile service using Hybrid Connections - Azure Mobile Services
trans-unit.target: Connect to an on-premises SQL Server from an Azure mobile service using Hybrid Connections - Azure Mobile Services

trans-unit.source: Learn how to connect to an on-premises SQL Server from an Azure mobile service using Hybrid Connections
trans-unit.target: Learn how to connect to an on-premises SQL Server from an Azure mobile service using Hybrid Connections

trans-unit.source: When your enterprise transitions to the cloud, you might not be able to migrate all of your assets to Azure right away.
trans-unit.target: When your enterprise transitions to the cloud, you might not be able to migrate all of your assets to Azure right away.

trans-unit.source: Hybrid Connections lets Azure Mobile Services securely connect to your on-premises assets.
trans-unit.target: Hybrid Connections lets Azure Mobile Services securely connect to your on-premises assets.

trans-unit.source: In this way, you can make your on-premises data accessible to your mobile clients by using Azure.
trans-unit.target: In this way, you can make your on-premises data accessible to your mobile clients by using Azure.

trans-unit.source: Supported assets include any resource that runs on a static TCP port, including Microsoft SQL Server, MySQL, HTTP Web APIs, and most custom web services.
trans-unit.target: Supported assets include any resource that runs on a static TCP port, including Microsoft SQL Server, MySQL, HTTP Web APIs, and most custom web services.

trans-unit.source: Hybrid Connections use Shared Access Signature (SAS) authorization to secure the connections from your mobile service and the on-premises Hybrid Connection Manager to the hybrid connection.
trans-unit.target: Hybrid Connections use Shared Access Signature (SAS) authorization to secure the connections from your mobile service and the on-premises Hybrid Connection Manager to the hybrid connection.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Hybrid Connections Overview</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Hybrid Connections Overview</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will learn how to modify a .NET backend mobile service to use a local on-premises SQL Server database instead of the default Azure SQL Database provisioned with your service.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will learn how to modify a .NET backend mobile service to use a local on-premises SQL Server database instead of the default Azure SQL Database provisioned with your service.

trans-unit.source: Hybrid Connections are also supported for a JavaScript backend mobile service, as described in <linkText>this article</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Hybrid Connections are also supported for a JavaScript backend mobile service, as described in <linkText>this article</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial requires you to have the following:
trans-unit.target: This tutorial requires you to have the following:

trans-unit.source:
An existing .NET backend mobile service
Follow the tutorial [Get started with Mobile Services] to create and download a new .NET backend mobile service from the [Azure Management Portal].
trans-unit.target:
An existing .NET backend mobile service
Follow the tutorial [Get started with Mobile Services] to create and download a new .NET backend mobile service from the [Azure Management Portal].

trans-unit.source: In this step, you define a connection string for the on-premises database and modify the mobile service to use this connection.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you define a connection string for the on-premises database and modify the mobile service to use this connection.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio 2013, open the project that defines your .NET backend mobile service.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio 2013, open the project that defines your .NET backend mobile service.

trans-unit.source: To learn how to download your .NET backend project, see <linkText>Get started with Mobile Services</linkText><title></title> .
trans-unit.target: To learn how to download your .NET backend project, see <linkText>Get started with Mobile Services</linkText><title></title> .

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, open the Web.config file, locate the connectionStrings section, add a new SqlClient entry like the following, which points to the on-premises SQL Server database:
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, open the Web.config file, locate the connectionStrings section, add a new SqlClient entry like the following, which points to the on-premises SQL Server database:

trans-unit.source: Remember to replace <**secure_password**> in this string with the password you created for the HbyridConnectionLogin.
trans-unit.target: Remember to replace <**secure_password**> in this string with the password you created for the HbyridConnectionLogin.

trans-unit.source: Click Save in Visual Studio to save the Web.config file.
trans-unit.target: Click Save in Visual Studio to save the Web.config file.

trans-unit.source: This connection setting is used when running on the local computer.
trans-unit.target: This connection setting is used when running on the local computer.

trans-unit.source: When running in Azure, this setting is overriden by the connection setting defined in the portal.
trans-unit.target: When running in Azure, this setting is overriden by the connection setting defined in the portal.

trans-unit.source: Expand the Models folder and open the data model file, which ends in Context.cs.
trans-unit.target: Expand the Models folder and open the data model file, which ends in Context.cs.

trans-unit.source: Modify the DbContext instance constructor to pass the value OnPremisesDBConnection to the base DbContext constructor, similar to the following snippet:
trans-unit.target: Modify the DbContext instance constructor to pass the value OnPremisesDBConnection to the base DbContext constructor, similar to the following snippet:

trans-unit.source: The service will now use the new connection to the SQL Server database.
trans-unit.target: The service will now use the new connection to the SQL Server database.

trans-unit.source: Before publishing to Azure and using the hybrid connection, it's a good idea to make sure that the database connection works when running locally.
trans-unit.target: Before publishing to Azure and using the hybrid connection, it's a good idea to make sure that the database connection works when running locally.

trans-unit.source: That way you can more easily diagnose and correct any connection issues before you republish and start using the hybrid connection.
trans-unit.target: That way you can more easily diagnose and correct any connection issues before you republish and start using the hybrid connection.

trans-unit.source: Now that you have verified the database connection, you need to add an app setting for this new connection string so that it can be used from Azure and publish the mobile service to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have verified the database connection, you need to add an app setting for this new connection string so that it can be used from Azure and publish the mobile service to Azure.

trans-unit.source: In the [Azure Management Portal], browse to your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: In the [Azure Management Portal], browse to your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Click the Configure tab, and locate Connection Strings section.
trans-unit.target: Click the Configure tab, and locate Connection Strings section.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Connection string for on-premises database</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Connection string for on-premises database</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Add an new connection SQL Server string named OnPremisesDBConnection with a value like the following:
trans-unit.target: Add an new connection SQL Server string named OnPremisesDBConnection with a value like the following:

trans-unit.source: Replace <**secure_password**> with the secure password for HybridConnectionLogin.
trans-unit.target: Replace <**secure_password**> with the secure password for HybridConnectionLogin.

trans-unit.source: Press Save to save the hybrid connection and connection string you just created.
trans-unit.target: Press Save to save the hybrid connection and connection string you just created.

trans-unit.source: Using Visual Studio, publish your updated mobile service project to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Using Visual Studio, publish your updated mobile service project to Azure.

trans-unit.source: The service start page is displayed.
trans-unit.target: The service start page is displayed.

trans-unit.source: Using either the Try it now button on the start page as before or using a client app connected to your mobile service, invoke some operations that generate database changes.
trans-unit.target: Using either the Try it now button on the start page as before or using a client app connected to your mobile service, invoke some operations that generate database changes.

trans-unit.source: When you use the Try it now button to launch the Help API pages, remember to supply your application key as the password (with a blank username).
trans-unit.target: When you use the Try it now button to launch the Help API pages, remember to supply your application key as the password (with a blank username).

trans-unit.source: In SQL Server Management Studio, connect to your SQL Server instance, open the Object Explorer, expand the OnPremisesDB database and expand Tables.
trans-unit.target: In SQL Server Management Studio, connect to your SQL Server instance, open the Object Explorer, expand the OnPremisesDB database and expand Tables.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the hybridService1.TodoItems table and choose Select Top 1000 Rows to view the results.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the hybridService1.TodoItems table and choose Select Top 1000 Rows to view the results.

trans-unit.source: Note that changes generated in your app have been saved by your mobile service to your on-premises database using the hybrid connection.
trans-unit.target: Note that changes generated in your app have been saved by your mobile service to your on-premises database using the hybrid connection.
